extractions: {"position": null, "sentence": "With respect to the two potential mediators meditation experience and daily self-reported motivation, we found that meditation experience is unrelated to accuracies (M = 1.80/3, SD = 0.56,  RPLUS MATCH ).  Motivation correlates positively with accuracy in this study (M = 3.98/5, SD = 0.92, r(224) = .18, p = .006", "statisticType": "cpearson_apa", "record": {"doF": "224", "pcor": ".18", "pval": ".006"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "For both distribution difference and mean specificity, we plotted the log of the normalized scores to preserve linearity. {"position": null, "sentence": "The analysis shows that neither the group nor the mode has a significant impact on the localization times.     Finally, based on the speed-accuracy tradeoff consideration\u00a0<cit.>, the hypothesis that participants could have adopted two different approaches to complete the task depending on their willingness was tested: either participant is quick but not accurate or accurate but slower.    However, a Pearson's correlation coefficient shows that there is no relation between the time taken to complete the localization task and the localization error (r(30) = 0.104,\u00a0p= 0.570)", "statisticType": "cpearson_apa", "record": {"doF": "30", "pcor": "0.104", "pval": "0.570"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "For the experience with robots score, we found a negative correlation with the Likeability subscale ( RPLUS MATCH ); for age, we found a positive correlation with the Likeability subscale (r(38) = .369, p = .019", "statisticType": "cpearson_apa", "record": {"doF": "38", "pcor": ".369", "pval": ".019"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "We also observed at least two instances in UC1 where domain experts explored the Pareto front in their own laptops.         \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Varying Complexity of Analysis Scenarios   The exploration scenarios identified vary in complexity, which we characterise with two measures: number of events and scenario duration.   In terms of average number of events per scenario type, Compare scenarios had the most number of events 7451,  followed by Alternative 6859,  Initial 5922,  New 4728,  Refine 4426,  and finally Storytelling 2632.  With the exception of Initial and Storytelling scenarios, overall the average time spent on each scenario type (in minutes) appears to be related to the average number of events in that scenario type: Compare 10.28m6.75,  Alternative 9m8.1,  Storytelling 7.33m8.15,  New 6.58m5,  Initial 6.25m3.59,  and Refine 5.9m3.74.   Indeed we found that scenario duration and event count were strongly correlated Pearson's r(68) = 0.77, p < 0.001", "statisticType": "cpearson_apa", "record": {"doF": "68", "pcor": "0.77", "pval": "0.001"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "The model was retrained on all sentences including the new compound sentences, and the cosine similarity was calculated between the user input sentence and the new compound sentence.       For each user, the average cosine similarity for all their teaching inputs was calculated, and used as an approximation of their paraphrasing effort across the teaching interaction.  Effect on Learning Outcomes: Considering the difference in test scores using all questions (`full learning outcomes'), a correlation is present with the cosine similarity, but the relationship is not statistically significant (r(46) = -0.293, p = .0628", "statisticType": "cpearson_apa", "record": {"doF": "46", "pcor": "-0.293", "pval": ".0628"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "All participants are able to complete the tasks with both modes by missing few objects (global average of 0.59\u00b10.78 missed obstacles). Considering the visual variables with respect to total immersion, a small correlation was found with screen width (r (401) =  0.276, p < 0.01), frames per second  RPLUS MATCH  (figure <ref> left), and contrast (r (401) = 0.125, p = 0.012)", "statisticType": "cpearson_apa", "record": {"doF": "401", "pcor": "0.125", "pval": "0.012"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "The model was retrained on all sentences including the new compound sentences, and the cosine similarity was calculated between the user input sentence and the new compound sentence.       For each user, the average cosine similarity for all their teaching inputs was calculated, and used as an approximation of their paraphrasing effort across the teaching interaction.  Effect on Learning Outcomes: Considering the difference in test scores using all questions (`full learning outcomes'), a correlation is present with the cosine similarity, but the relationship is not statistically significant ( RPLUS MATCH ).  Considering only rock-specific questions ('rock-specific learning outcomes'), a statistically significant correlation is present between cosine similarity and rock-specific learning outcomes (r(46) = -0.354, p = .0233", "statisticType": "cpearson_apa", "record": {"doF": "46", "pcor": "-0.354", "pval": ".0233"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}
